answer_html: However, clearly A has only one linearly independent column, so \(\text{Rank}(A) = \#\text{ of distinct eigenvalues.}\)
answer_latex:
However,
clearly \emph{A} has only one linearly independent column, so
$\text{Rank}(A) = \#\text{ of distinct eigenvalues.}$
question: 12 (h)
sols_html:
The answer is false. Consider the matrix

\(A = \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 \end{pmatrix}.\)

A has two distinct eigenvalues, 0 and 1. However, clearly A has only one linearly independent column, so \(\text{Rank}(A) = 1 < 2 = \#\text{ of distinct eigenvalues.}\)
sols_latex:
The answer is \textbf{false}. Consider the matrix

$A = \begin{pmatrix}
1 & 0 \\
0 & 0
\end{pmatrix}.$

\emph{A} has two distinct eigenvalues, \emph{0} and \emph{1}. However,
clearly \emph{A} has only one linearly independent column, so
$\text{Rank}(A) = 1 < 2 = \#\text{ of distinct eigenvalues.}$
sols_raw:
The answer is '''false'''.  Consider the matrix 

<math>
A = \begin{pmatrix}
1 & 0 \\
0 & 0
\end{pmatrix}.
</math>

''A'' has two distinct eigenvalues, ''0'' and ''1''.  However, clearly ''A'' has only one linearly independent column, so <math>\text{Rank}(A) = 1 < 2 = \#\text{ of distinct eigenvalues.} </math>
statement_html: If a matrix A has \(k\) distinct eigenvalues, then \(\text{Rank}(A) \geq k\).
statement_latex:
If a matrix \emph{A} has $k$ distinct eigenvalues, then
$\text{Rank}(A) \geq k$.
statement_raw: If a matrix ''A'' has <math>k</math> distinct eigenvalues, then <math>\text{Rank}(A) \geq k</math>.
